answer_html: \(\int_{4}^{9} e^{\sqrt{x}} dx=4e^{3}-2e^{2}\) completing the integral.
hints_html:
What seems to be complicated? Try using a substitution to get rid of the complicated part.

Try substituting \(u = \sqrt{x}\)

Try to integrate by parts now.
hints_latex:
What seems to be complicated? Try using a substitution to get rid of the
complicated part.
Try to integrate by parts now.
hints_raw:
What seems to be complicated? Try using a substitution to get rid of the complicated part.
Try substituting <math> u = \sqrt{x} </math>
Try to integrate by parts now.
question: 4 (a)
sols_html:
Let \(u = \sqrt{x}\) so \(du = \frac{dx}{2\sqrt{x}}\).

Cross multiplying yields \(2\sqrt{x}du = dx\).

Since \(u = \sqrt{x}\), the above is equal to \(\displaystyle 2udu = dx\).

Note further that \(u(4) = \sqrt{4} = 2\) and \(u(9) = \sqrt{9} = 3\)

Substituting gives

\(\int_{4}^{9} e^{\sqrt{x}} dx = \int_{2}^{3} 2ue^{u}du = 2\int_{2}^{3} ue^{u}du\)

We integrate by parts. Let \(v=u\) and \(dw = e^{u}du\) so

\[\begin{aligned} v = u \quad&\quad w = e^{u}\\ dv = du \quad&\quad dw = e^{u}du\end{aligned}\]

Hence

\[\begin{aligned} \int_{4}^{9} e^{\sqrt{x}} dx &= 2\int_{2}^{3} ue^{u}du \\ &= 2(ue^{u}\mid_{2}^{3} - \int_{2}^{3} e^{u}du)\\ &= 2(3e^{3}-2e^{2} - e^{u}\mid_{2}^{3})\\ &= 2(3e^{3}-2e^{2} - e^{3} + e^{2})\\ &= 2(2e^{3}-e^{2})\\ &= 4e^{3}-2e^{2}\end{aligned}\]

completing the integral.
sols_latex:
Let $u = \sqrt{x}$ so $du = \frac{dx}{2\sqrt{x}}$.

Cross multiplying yields $2\sqrt{x}du = dx$.

Since $u = \sqrt{x}$, the above is equal to $\displaystyle 2udu = dx$.

Note further that $u(4) = \sqrt{4} = 2$ and $u(9) = \sqrt{9} = 3$

Substituting gives

$\int_{4}^{9} e^{\sqrt{x}} dx = \int_{2}^{3} 2ue^{u}du = 2\int_{2}^{3} ue^{u}du$

We integrate by parts. Let $v=u$ and $dw = e^{u}du$ so

\begin{align*}
v = u \quad&\quad w = e^{u}\\
dv = du \quad&\quad dw = e^{u}du
\end{align*}

Hence \begin{align*}
\int_{4}^{9} e^{\sqrt{x}} dx &= 2\int_{2}^{3} ue^{u}du \\ 
&= 2(ue^{u}\mid_{2}^{3} - \int_{2}^{3} e^{u}du)\\
&= 2(3e^{3}-2e^{2} - e^{u}\mid_{2}^{3})\\
&= 2(3e^{3}-2e^{2} - e^{3} + e^{2})\\
&= 2(2e^{3}-e^{2})\\
&= 4e^{3}-2e^{2}
\end{align*}

completing the integral.
sols_raw:
Let <math>u = \sqrt{x}</math> so <math>du = \frac{dx}{2\sqrt{x}}</math>. 

Cross multiplying yields <math> 2\sqrt{x}du = dx</math>. 

Since <math> u = \sqrt{x}</math>, the above is equal to <math>\displaystyle 2udu = dx</math>.

Note further that <math> u(4) = \sqrt{4} = 2</math> and <math> u(9) = \sqrt{9} = 3</math>

Substituting gives

<math>
\int_{4}^{9} e^{\sqrt{x}} dx = \int_{2}^{3} 2ue^{u}du = 2\int_{2}^{3} ue^{u}du 
</math>

We integrate by parts. Let <math>v=u</math> and <math>dw = e^{u}du</math> so

<math>
\begin{align}
v = u \quad&\quad w = e^{u}\\
dv = du \quad&\quad dw = e^{u}du
\end{align}
</math>

Hence
<math>
\begin{align}
\int_{4}^{9} e^{\sqrt{x}} dx &= 2\int_{2}^{3} ue^{u}du \\ 
&= 2(ue^{u}\mid_{2}^{3} - \int_{2}^{3} e^{u}du)\\
&= 2(3e^{3}-2e^{2} - e^{u}\mid_{2}^{3})\\
&= 2(3e^{3}-2e^{2} - e^{3} + e^{2})\\
&= 2(2e^{3}-e^{2})\\
&= 4e^{3}-2e^{2}
\end{align}
</math>

completing the integral.

Compute the following integrals. (Leave your answers in terms of \(e\) or \(\ln()\).)

\[\begin{aligned} I = \int_4^9 e^{\sqrt{x}}\,dx\end{aligned}\]
